data.value: This primarily exists to be called during the
. It can also be used to determine the value of
for many different convolutions of the same dtype/shape. In addition, it supports timing the convolution to adapt the value of
to a particular set of inputs and/or hardware.
Generally, this method is 99% accurate for 2D signals and 85% accurate for 1D signals for randomly chosen input sizes. For precision, use
to find the fastest method by timing the convolution. This can be used to avoid the minimal overhead of finding the fastest
later, or to adapt the value of
to a particular set of inputs.
Experiments were run on an Amazon EC2 r5a.2xlarge machine to test this function. These experiments measured the ratio between the time required when using
and the time required for the fastest method (i.e.,
There is a 95% chance of this ratio being less than 1.5 for 1D signals   and a 99% chance of being less than 2.5 for 2D signals.
The ratio was always less than 2.5/5 for 1D/2D signals respectively.
This function is most inaccurate for 1D convolutions that take between 1   and 10 milliseconds with
. A good proxy for this   (at least in our experiments) is
The 2D results almost certainly generalize to 3D/4D/etc because the implementation is the same (the 1D implementation is different).

All the numbers above are specific to the EC2 machine. However, we did find that this function generalizes fairly decently across hardware. The speed tests were of similar quality (and even slightly better) than the same tests performed on the machine to tune this function's numbers (a mid-2014 15-inch MacBook Pro with 16GB RAM and a 2.5GHz Intel i7 processor).
